title: Westland, Michigan
text:
Westland is a <a href="city">city</a> in <a href="Wayne%20County%2C%20Michigan">Wayne County</a> in the U.S. state of <a href="Michigan">Michigan</a>. It is located about west of downtown <a href="Detroit">Detroit</a>. As of the <a href="2010%20United%20States%20Census">2010 census</a>, the city had a total population of 84,094. It is the 10th largest city and 12th largest <a href="List%20of%20municipalities%20in%20Michigan">municipality in Michigan</a>.
History.
Early history.
During the 18th century, the area was inhabited by the people of a <a href="Potawatomi">Potawatomi</a> Native American village. Other tribes, particularly three <a href="Algonquian%20peoples">Algonquian</a> tribes, used the area as hunting territory. Though white settlers did not begin to settle the area until about 1824, they began passing through at the beginning of the 19th century.
Before becoming Westland, the area had several other names. In 1827, the area became known as Bucklin Township, which included what is now the cities of Westland, <a href="Livonia%2C%20Michigan">Livonia</a>, <a href="Garden%20City%2C%20Michigan">Garden City</a>, <a href="Inkster%2C%20Michigan">Inkster</a>, <a href="Wayne%2C%20Michigan">Wayne</a>, <a href="Dearborn%2C%20Michigan">Dearborn</a>, <a href="Dearborn%20Heights%2C%20Michigan">Dearborn Heights</a> and <a href="Redford%20Township%2C%20Michigan">Redford Township</a>. In 1829, it was proposed that Bucklin Township be divided into Lima and Richland; the former is what eventually became Westland. Due to name conflicts under territorial law prohibiting duplication of post office names, Lima was renamed <a href="Nankin%20Township%2C%20Michigan">Nankin Township</a>, after the Chinese city of <a href="Nanjing">Nanking</a>.
Later history.
Nankin Township was mostly rural until World War II. <a href="Norwayne%20Historic%20District">Norwayne subdivision</a> is one of the oldest areas of the city, having existed for over 65 years. The area was built immediately after <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> to provide temporary housing for returning soldiers who worked in nearby factories.
By 1960, Nankin Township's population had increased to 70,000, giving the area the distinction of being the state's largest township. During the early 1960s, the city of Livonia wanted to annex the part of Nankin in which a large shopping mall, <a href="Westland%20Center">Westland Shopping Center</a>, was to be built. The shopping center eventually opened in 1965, joining Northland and Eastland malls in <a href="Southfield%2C%20Michigan">Southfield</a> and <a href="Harper%20Woods">Harper Woods</a>, respectively. In reaction to Livonia's annexation attempts, the people of Nankin voted on May 16, 1966, to change the remainder of the township to the City of Westland. At that time, it was the fourth largest city in Wayne County.
Politics.
The current mayor of Westland is William (Bill) Wild. Mr. Wild took office in January 2007 and continues to serve as mayor.
The legislative body of Westland is the City Council, which contains seven members. The current President of the City Council is James Hart. Other Council members are Council President Pro-Tem Michael Londeau, Peter Herzberg, Andrea Rutkowski, Mike McDermott, James Godbout, and Melissa Sampey.
Education.
Westland and the city of Wayne form the <a href="Wayne-Westland%20Community%20School%20District">Wayne-Westland Community School District</a>. There are four high schools, <a href="John%20Glenn%20High%20School%20%28Westland%2C%20Michigan%29">John Glenn</a>, Tinkham Center, and William D. Ford Career Tech Center in Westland, and <a href="Wayne%20Memorial%20High%20School">Wayne Memorial</a> in Wayne. There is a historical site, <a href="Perrinsville%20School">Perrinsville School</a> in Westland on Warren Road. Nearly all students that live in the city of Wayne go to Wayne Memorial High School, along with some residents of Van Buren Township, Inkster, Romulus, Canton and southern Westland. Students in central Westland and portions of northern Westland, as well as isolated areas of neighboring Inkster and Canton, attend John Glenn High School. The northernmost portions of Westland are in the <a href="Livonia%20Public%20Schools">Livonia Public Schools</a> district.
Portions of Westland that had been in the <a href="Taylor%20School%20District%20%28Michigan%29">Taylor School District</a> prior to the 2013 dissolution of the <a href="Inkster%20School%20District">Inkster School District</a> are assigned to Taylor Parks Elementary School, Hoover Middle School, and <a href="Harry%20S.%20Truman%20High%20School%20%28Taylor%2C%20Michigan%29">Harry S. Truman High School</a> in <a href="Taylor%2C%20Michigan">Taylor</a>.
Portions in Livonia School District are assigned to Hayes (in Westland), Rosedale, Garfield, and Cleveland K-4 elementary schools. 5-6 elementary schools include Johnson Upper Elementary School (in Westland) and Cooper Upper Elementary School (in Westland). Livonia SD middle schools serving Westland include Frost and Emerson. Livonia SD high schools serving Westland include <a href="Churchill%20High%20School%20%28Livonia%29">Churchill High School</a> and <a href="Franklin%20High%20School%20%28Livonia%29">Franklin High School</a>.
There is a portion of southeastern Westland that is currently divided between <a href="Romulus%20Community%20Schools">Romulus Community Schools</a> and the Taylor School District that was previously assigned to the Inkster School District. <a href="Romulus%20Senior%20High%20School">Romulus Senior High School</a> is the assigned high school for Romulus students. Students in the Inkster zone previously attended <a href="Inkster%20High%20School">Inkster High School</a>.
There is a <a href="charter%20school">charter school</a> in Westland, <a href="Universal%20Learning%20Academy">Universal Learning Academy</a>.
Private schools:
St. Damian Catholic School in Westland closed in 2016.
Geography.
According to the <a href="United%20States%20Census%20Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a>, the city has a total area of , of which is land and is water.
Demographics.
2010 census.
As of the <a href="census">census</a> of 2010, there were 84,094 people, 35,886 households, and 21,289 families living in the city. The <a href="population%20density">population density</a> was . There were 39,201 housing units at an average density of . The racial makeup of the city was 75.8% <a href="White%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">White</a>, 17.2% <a href="African%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">African American</a>, 0.5% <a href="Native%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 3.0% <a href="Asian%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Asian</a>, 1.1% from <a href="Race%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">other races</a>, and 2.4% from two or more races. <a href="Hispanic%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Hispanic</a> or <a href="Latino%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Latino</a> residents of any race were 3.8% of the population.
There were 35,886 households, of which 29.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 37.5% were <a href="Marriage">married couples</a> living together, 16.4% had a female householder with no husband present, 5.4% had a male householder with no wife present, and 40.7% were non-families. 34.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 12.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.31 and the average family size was 2.98.
The median age in the city was 38.3 years. 22.1% of residents were under the age of 18; 9.5% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 27.7% were from 25 to 44; 26.6% were from 45 to 64; and 14% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 47.5% male and 52.5% female.
2000 census.
As of the <a href="census">census</a> of 2000, there were 86,602 people, 36,533 households, and 22,248 families living in the city. The <a href="population%20density">population density</a> was 4,234.9 per square mile (1,635.1/km2). There were 38,077 housing units at an average density of 1,862.0 per square mile (718.9/km2). The racial makeup of the city was 87.21% <a href="White%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">White</a>, 6.77% <a href="African%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">African American</a>, 0.46% <a href="Native%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 2.81% <a href="Asian%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Asian</a>, 0.03% <a href="Pacific%20Islander%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Pacific Islander</a>, 0.67% from <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">other races</a>, and 2.04% from two or more races. <a href="Hispanic%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Hispanic</a> or <a href="Latino%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Latino</a> of any race were 2.47% of the population.
There were 36,533 households, out of which 28.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 44.4% were <a href="Marriage">married couples</a> living together, 12.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 39.1% were non-families. 32.6% of all households were made up of individuals, and 11.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.34 and the average family size was 3.00.
In the city, the population was spread out, with 23.3% under the age of 18, 9.0% from 18 to 24, 33.9% from 25 to 44, 20.6% from 45 to 64, and 13.2% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 35 years. For every 100 females, there were 92.6 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 89.6 males.
The median income for a household in the city was $46,308, and the median income for a family was $55,323. Males had a median income of $45,111 versus $30,143 for females. The <a href="per%20capita%20income">per capita income</a> for the city was $22,615. About 4.7% of families and 6.8% of the population were below the <a href="poverty%20line">poverty line</a>, including 7.6% of those under age 18 and 6.9% of those age 65 or over.
City services.
Westland has a full-time police department and fire department. The fire department offers advanced <a href="emergency%20medical%20services">EMS</a>, fire protection and prevention, and several specialized rescue teams.
The city is known for having an abundance of parks. Hines Park (wayne county parks) is located in the northern region of Westland. Residents along this corridor enjoy seeing deer, fox and hummingbirds all year long as well as easy access to the bike paths of Hines Park. Westland also has numerous City owned parks throughout many of the neighborhoods.
The Westland Public Library offers books, magazines, CDs, <a href="playaway">playaway</a>s, videos, DVDs and electronic materials through access to subscription databases.
The City of Westland offers automated recycling services. For waste disposal, residents have black bins for garbage, and blue bins for recycling. Recycle bins are picked up every other week, while trash is picked up weekly.
The former Eloise psychiatric hospital is due as of 2021 to be redeveloped as a commercial centre and hotel. The building dates back to 1839: the <a href="Wayne%20County%20Hospital">Wayne County Hospital</a> ceased operating from the site in 1984, and it was used as offices for Wayne County employees up until 2016.
